faq.question: What credit score do I need to buy a house?
faq.answer: For conventional loans, you typically need a minimum credit score of 620. FHA loans are more flexible and accept scores as low as 580 (or even 500 with a larger down payment). The higher your score, the better your interest rate. If you're below 620, I recommend working with a credit repair specialist for 3-6 months before applying.

faq.question: How much do I need for a down payment?
faq.answer: It depends on your loan type. FHA loans require as little as 3.5% down. Conventional loans typically need 5-20% (putting down 20% avoids PMI insurance). VA loans for veterans require $0 down. For a $600k home, that's $21k (FHA), $30k-120k (conventional), or $0 (VA). First-time buyers often qualify for assistance programs that can cover $5k-15k of your down payment.

faq.question: What is PMI and can I avoid it?
faq.answer: PMI (Private Mortgage Insurance) is required on conventional loans when you put down less than 20%. It costs $50-250/month depending on your loan amount. You can avoid it by: (1) putting 20% down, (2) getting a piggyback loan (80-10-10 structure), or (3) using an FHA loan (which has MIP instead, but lower upfront cost). PMI automatically drops off once you reach 20% equity.

faq.question: How long does it take to close on a house?
faq.answer: Typical timeline is 30-45 days from offer acceptance to closing. Cash buyers can close in 7-14 days. The process includes: inspection (7-10 days), appraisal (10-14 days), underwriting (10-20 days), and final walkthrough. Delays happen if there are repair negotiations or appraisal issues. Pre-approval speeds things up significantly.

faq.question: What is the difference between pre-qualification and pre-approval?
faq.answer: Pre-qualification is a quick estimate based on self-reported info (takes 1 day, not verified). Pre-approval is a full underwriting where the lender verifies your income, credit, and assets (takes 3-5 days). Sellers take pre-approved buyers seriously because they're 90% guaranteed to close. I always recommend getting pre-approved before house hunting—it gives you negotiating power.

faq.question: Should I waive the inspection to make my offer stronger?
faq.answer: I strongly advise against waiving inspections, even in competitive markets. Instead, shorten the inspection period (5 days instead of 10) or offer an 'inspection for information only' clause (you'll still inspect but won't ask for repairs). Major issues like foundation problems or mold can cost $20k-100k to fix. A $400-600 inspection protects you from buying a money pit.

faq.question: How much should I offer below asking price?
faq.answer: It depends on market conditions. In hot markets (like Rancho Cucamonga), homes often sell at or above asking. In buyer's markets, 5-10% below asking is reasonable. I analyze comparable sales (comps) to determine fair value. If a home is priced at $700k but comps show $680k, we'd offer $675k-685k. Days on market also matter—if it's been listed 60+ days, sellers are more motivated.

faq.question: What are closing costs and how much are they?
faq.answer: Closing costs are fees paid at closing (separate from down payment). They're typically 2-3% of the purchase price in California. For a $700k home, expect $14k-21k. This includes: loan origination ($1k-2k), appraisal ($500-700), title insurance ($1k-2k), escrow fees ($1k-2k), property taxes (prorated), and recording fees ($200-500). You can ask the seller to cover some closing costs in your offer.

faq.question: How do I price my home to sell quickly?
faq.answer: Price it at or slightly below market value based on recent comps. Overpricing by even 5% can cause your home to sit for months (then you'll need to drop the price, which makes buyers suspicious). I run a Comparative Market Analysis (CMA) looking at 3-5 similar homes sold in the last 90 days. Homes priced right sell within 2 weeks and often get multiple offers, driving the price up naturally.

faq.question: Do I need to make repairs before listing?
faq.answer: Focus on high-ROI fixes: fresh paint ($500 returns $2k), deep cleaning ($200 returns $1k), landscaping ($300 returns $1.5k), and minor repairs (leaky faucets, broken fixtures). Don't renovate kitchens or bathrooms unless they're severely outdated—you won't recoup the cost. Buyers expect some wear and tear. Big issues (roof, HVAC, foundation) can be disclosed and priced accordingly.

faq.question: Is now a good time to buy or should I wait?
faq.answer: Trying to time the market is risky. If you're financially ready (stable income, 6-month emergency fund, pre-approved), buy when you find the right home. Waiting for rates or prices to drop can backfire—Rancho Cucamonga's median home price has risen steadily due to its popularity. Even if prices dip 5%, rising interest rates could cost you more monthly. Real estate is a long-term investment (7+ years).

faq.question: How do rising interest rates affect my buying power?
faq.answer: Every 1% increase in interest rates costs you ~$200/month per $300k borrowed. At 4% on $600k loan = $2,864/month. At 6% = $3,597/month. That's $733/month or $264k over 30 years. This is why pre-approval is critical—lock in your rate for 60-90 days. If rates are rising, consider paying points (1 point = 1% of loan amount) to lower your rate by 0.25%.

faq.question: What are the best family-friendly neighborhoods in Rancho Cucamonga?
faq.answer: Top picks: (1) Etiwanda—premier schools (9/10 rating), newer luxury homes, $800k-1.2M; (2) Alta Loma—mountain views, large lots, custom homes, $750k-1.5M; (3) Victoria Gardens Area—walkable shopping, modern townhomes, $600k-850k; (4) Terra Vista—planned community, parks, pools, $650k-900k. All have low crime, great amenities, and easy 210 freeway access.

faq.question: Which Rancho Cucamonga neighborhoods are walkable?
faq.answer: Highly walkable: (1) Victoria Gardens—premier shopping, dining, and lifestyle center with nearby residential, Walk Score 80+; (2) Central Rancho—close to amenities and parks; (3) Foothill Blvd Corridor—easy access to services. Rancho Cucamonga is primarily suburban, but the Victoria Gardens area offers a truly urban-suburban mix.

faq.question: Is buying rental property in Rancho Cucamonga a good investment?
faq.answer: Rancho Cucamonga has strong rental demand from logistics professionals, healthcare workers, and families. Cap rates are stable (4-5%) but offset by strong historical appreciation. Best areas: South Rancho ($550k-700k homes, high demand), Etiwanda (executive rentals), Victoria Gardens (professional condos). Vacancy rates are low. Long-term growth in the Inland Empire drives appreciation.

faq.question: Do I need a real estate attorney?
faq.answer: In California, attorneys aren't required for standard residential transactions (escrow companies handle closings). However, I recommend an attorney if: (1) buying foreclosure/short sale, (2) complex contract terms, (3) boundary disputes, (4) estate/trust sales. For standard transactions, your agent and escrow company provide adequate protection.

faq.question: What do home inspectors check?
faq.answer: Inspectors examine: (1) Foundation/structure (cracks, settling), (2) Roof (age, leaks, shingle condition), (3) HVAC (functionality, age), (4) Plumbing (leaks, water pressure, sewer line), (5) Electrical (panel, wiring, outlets), (6) Windows/doors, (7) Attic/insulation. They DON'T check: cosmetic issues, appliances (unless specified), pest damage (separate inspection required in CA). Major red flags: foundation issues, old roof, outdated electrical.

faq.question: What happens if the appraisal comes in low?
faq.answer: If appraisal < purchase price, you have 4 options: (1) Renegotiate price down to appraisal, (2) Bring extra cash to cover the gap, (3) Meet seller halfway, (4) Walk away (if you have appraisal contingency). Smart move: Include appraisal contingency in your offer to protect yourself in competitive Southern California markets.

faq.question: How much are property taxes in Rancho Cucamonga?
faq.answer: California property taxes are governed by Proposition 13, which limits the base tax rate to 1% of the assessed value (purchase price) plus local bonds and assessments (Mello-Roos). In Rancho Cucamonga (San Bernardino County), expect a total effective rate of ~1.1% to 1.4%. Taxes increase by no more than 2% annually. Good news: California has no 'tax cliff'—your taxes stay predictable as long as you own the home.

faq.question: Should I sell my current home before buying a new one?
faq.answer: It depends on your finances. Selling first = no mortgage contingency (stronger offer), but you might need temporary housing. Buying first = seamless move, but you'll carry 2 mortgages temporarily. Middle ground: Home sale contingency or bridge loan. I can connect you with lenders who specialize in bridge loans for Southern California homeowners.
